In the past, I often faced setbacks, and nothing seemed to go my way,
as if walking against a harsh wind, struggling with every step.
But fate has its timing, and fortune eventually turns.
One day, an opportunity quietly arrived; the difficulties loosened,
and my worries faded with it.
Only then did I understand that life moves in cycles —
when darkness reaches its peak, light follows.
When luck arrives, everything naturally flows.
One must stay steady in heart and firm in purpose,
waiting for the right moment —
for only then can one witness the beauty of life’s turning tides.

　　破解謎題，就能成為億萬富翁，你，敢不敢玩這場遊戲？

　　「為什麼一個陌生人會把遺產留給我？」

　　艾芙瑞計畫好的未來是這樣：撐過高中畢業、贏得獎學金，早點開始工作，脫離貧困生活。但是，當全美第九大富豪、身價462億的霍桑先生過世之後，她的命運瞬間產生巨大變化。他把大部分的財產都留給艾芙瑞，並留下一句話：親愛的艾芙瑞，對不起。

　　問題是－－為什麼？她甚至根本不知道霍桑是誰。

　　為了繼承遺產，她必須在霍桑的豪宅住滿一年，而整座莊園擁有各種祕密通道、機關，處處透露霍桑對拼圖、謎語和密碼的熱愛。不幸的是，霍桑的四個孫子也正等著她。

　　他們英俊、魅力十足且聰明，但好壞難辨；老大奈許看起來置身事外，只想當個浪子；二哥格雷森堅信艾芙瑞是個騙子，排行第三的詹姆森視她為祖父最後的謎題，而老么亞歷山大則是聰明絕頂的天才，但她看不清他是敵是友。

　　在這個充滿金錢、特權且危機四伏的世界，每一個謎題、每一個轉折都是關鍵。為了生存，艾芙瑞必須立刻學會玩好這場繼承者的遊戲－－

作者簡介

珍妮佛．琳恩．巴尼斯（Jennifer Lynn Barnes）

　　生於俄克拉荷馬州。她曾是競技啦啦隊選手、排球員、舞者、靈長類意識研究員、模特兒，也是漫畫與狐猴的粉絲。自她有記憶以來就喜歡創作，高中時完成人生的第一本小說。2012年，她取得耶魯大學博士學位，擁有心理學、精神病學和認知科學學位，現在是奧克拉荷馬大學心理學與專業寫作教授，研究領域為小說與粉絲團的心理學。

Ang karaniwang malamig at kalmadong mukha ng lalaki ay tila humalina habang nakayuko siya sa babaeng nasa larawan.

Makalipas ang ilang sandali, nakabawi siya, hinanap ang numero ni Sean at tinawagan siya. Naghintay siya nang matagal hanggang sa mag-signal ang busy tone at sa wakas ay narinig ang natatanging boses ng lalaki mula sa kabilang linya. "Ano ang kailangan mo?"

"Uuwi ka ba ngayong gabi?" Ang totoo, gusto niyang itanong kung gusto niyang umuwi.

Sa kasamaang-palad, kitang-kita na naiirita siya sa tawag pa lang. Kaya, pagkatapos ng ilang segundo ng katahimikan, imbyernado niyang sinabi: "May importante ba tayong pag-uusapan?"

Agad na nanagan ang mga luha sa kanyang mga mata, ang walang-emosyon na boses nito ay parang patalim na tumusok sa kanyang puso, ngunit mahusay niyang itinago ang kalungkutan. "Nakalimutan mo na ba kung anong araw ngayon?"

Tatlong taon na silang secretong kasal, ngunit bihira silang magkita. Ngayon ay ang kanilang anibersaryo ng kasal, ang araw na dapat ay uuwi siya. Nangako siya sa kanya na ipagdiriwang niya ito kasama siya.

Sa kasamaang-palad, pinutol lang niya siya at mainip na nabulong: "Mamaya na ako uuwi." 'Wag kang mag-alala.

Pagkatapos noon, hindi na siya nag-aksaya ng ora. Sumikip ang puso ni Abigail nang marinig ang monotono na tono ng pagdi-dial. Kaya, itinilampak niya ang kanyang ulo at nag-recover sa pamamagitan ng paghinga nang malalim ng ilang beses. Sa huli, tinawagan niya ang kanyang matalik na kaibigan na si Luna Smith para sunduin siya.

### Kabanata 1: Maghiwalay Na Tayo  
*"Ang asawa mo ay kasama ng ibang babae."*  

Nang makatanggap si Abigail Quinn ng text message mula sa kanyang matalik na kaibigan, kakagawa lang niya ng oval injection at nagpapahinga sa bench ng outpatient clinic habang tinitiis ang matinding sakit sa kanyang tiyan. Itim ang kanyang buhok at maputla ang kanyang balat na parang yelo, ngunit hindi nito nababawasan ang kanyang kagandahan. Patuloy pa ring lingon-lingon ang mga tao para lang siya ay masilayan.  

Pagkatapos, huminga siya nang malalim at binuksan ang larawan sa kanyang cellphone gamit ang nanginginig na daliri. Ito ay larawan ni Shane Graham na mayakap ang isang babaeng nakasuot ng kulay rosas na damit palabas ng isang hotel. Ang lalaking karaniwang may malamig at walang emosyong mukha ay tila mas malambot habang nakayuko sa babaeng nasa larawan.  

Alam ni Abigail kung sino ang babaeng iyon—ang unang pag-ibig ni Shane, si Jane Palmer.  

Sandali matapos ito, natauhan siya, hinanap ang numero ni Shane, at tumawag. Naghintay siya ng matagal hanggang sa magpatong ang busy dial tone, at sa wakas ay may narinig na malamig na boses mula sa kabilang linya. "Ano'ng problema?"  

"Uuwi ka ba ngayong gabi?" Sa totoo lang, gusto niyang itanong kung nais pa ba nitong umuwi.  

Sa kasamaang-palad, maliwanag na naiinis si Shane sa kanyang tawag. Pagkatapos ng ilang segundo ng katahimikan, impatient niyang sinabi, "May importante bang problema na kailangan nating pag-usapan?"  

Agad na napuno ng luha ang kanyang mga mata. Ang kanyang malayo at malamig na boses ay parang tinusok ang kanyang puso, ngunit mahusay niyang itinago ang kanyang paghihirap. "Nakalimutan mo na ba kung anong araw ngayon?"  

Tatlong taon na silang ikinasal nang palihim, ngunit bihira silang magkita. Ngayon ay anibersaryo ng kanilang kasal, ang araw na dapat ay uuwi siya. Nangako siya na ipagdiwang niya ito kasama siya.  

Sa kasamaang-palad, pinutol lang siya nito at umungol na may inis, "Darating ako mamaya. Huwag kang mag-alala."  

Pagkatapos noon, agad itong nagpatay ng telepono. Sumidhi ang lungkot ni Abigail nang marinig niya ang nanlait na dial tone. Chapter 16: The Shape of Trust

Trust arrived slowly, almost unnoticed. Not as a promise, but as a pattern.

Amelia realized it one afternoon when she missed a call from Miles and didn’t panic. No spiraling thoughts. No rehearsed apologies. Just a quiet assumption: he’ll call back. And he did—later than planned, voice warm, unhurried.

“Sorry, I got caught up,” he said.

“No worries,” she replied—and meant it.

That evening, rain tapped softly against the windows as they cooked dinner together, moving around each other with an ease that felt earned. Miles chopped vegetables while Amelia stirred the pot, the domestic simplicity grounding.

“I used to think trust was something you declared,” Miles said suddenly. “Like a line you crossed once and never looked back.”

“And now?” Amelia asked.

“Now I think it’s something you practice,” he said. “Every day. In small choices.”

She considered this, nodding. “Like telling the truth even when it’s awkward. Or staying present when it would be easier to shut down.”

He glanced at her, a small smile forming. “Exactly like that.”

Later, curled together on the couch, Amelia rested her head on his shoulder. The weight felt natural, not borrowed, not owed.

“If one day you need space,” she said softly, “I trust you’ll tell me.”

“And if you need reassurance,” he replied, “I trust you’ll ask.”

The agreement wasn’t spoken like a rule. It was offered like a gift.

Outside, the rain slowed to a whisper. Inside, something settled—solid, quiet, real.

Trust, Amelia realized, didn’t demand proof.
It revealed itself in consistency.

And for the first time, she wasn’t watching for cracks.
She was living inside the safety of what was.

"Subukan mo at ang bisikleta mo ay magiging motorsiklo." Ang salawikain na ito, na puno ng karunungan sa katutubo, ay nagpapakita ng isang pangunahing lohika tungkol sa kaligtasan ng buhay at mga tagumpay: kapag nakulong sa tiyak na katotohanan ng isang "bisikleta," tanging sa pamamagitan lamang ng paglaya mula sa nakasanayang mga hadlang maaabot ng isang tao ang mas mataas na dimensyon na sinasagisag ng "motorsiklo." Ang "laban" na ito ay hindi isang bulag na sugal, ngunit sa halip ay isang survivalist na karunungan na nagpapagana ng potensyal sa mga desperado na sitwasyon at sinasamantala ang mga bitak ng kapalaran. Ito ay nagpapahiwatig ng tatlong malalim na praktikal at espirituwal na lohika.

Ang mga bisikleta ay kumakatawan sa isang hindi mahusay na steady state—ang dalas ng pagpedal ay proporsyonal sa bilis ng pasulong, at ang pagsisikap at gantimpala ay linearly na magkakaugnay. Katulad ni Lin Ye, isang hamak na deliveryman sa kuwento, na nagpapagal sa mga lansangan araw-araw, naniniwala siyang iikot lang ang buhay sa pag-ikot ng "mga gamit ng bisikleta." Ngunit nang tumagos ang bala ng pumatay sa basket ng bisikleta, ang steady state na ito ay marahas na nagambala. Ang umiiral na krisis ay nagpilit sa kanya na mag-isip sa labas ng kahon: Ang patuloy na pagtakas ayon sa "lohika ng bisikleta" ay mangangahulugan lamang na madurog ng lakas-kabayo ng kotse. Sa pamamagitan lamang ng pagliko ng bisikleta patungo sa panganib, gamit ang isang radikal na "motorsiklo" na diskarte, maaari siyang lumikha ng isang pagkakataon para mabuhay sa gitna ng pagkagambala sa bilis at direksyon. Naaayon ito sa "batas ng pagkawalang-galaw" sa pisika: ang mga bagay sa pahinga ay may posibilidad na manatili sa pahinga, at ang mga bagay na gumagalaw ay madalas na gumagalaw sa isang pare-parehong bilis. Ang "puwersa" na nagbabago sa estado ng pagkawalang-kilos ay kadalasang nagmumula sa isang "pakikibaka" na lumalabag sa kombensyon.

Ang ubod ng pagbabagong "bisikleta-sa-motorsiklo" ay nakasalalay sa matinding kawalan ng timbang sa pagitan ng panganib at gantimpala. Ang isang bisikleta ay mura, at kahit na ito ay nawala, walang kaunting mawawala. Ang isang motorsiklo, sa kabilang banda, ay kumakatawan sa isang paglukso sa kahusayan at isang paglukso sa mga klase sa lipunan, na may mga gantimpala na mas malaki kaysa sa panganib. Katulad ng desisyon ni Lin Ye na i-activate ang kanyang banal na proteksyon sa panahon ng bagyo, napagsapalaran niya ang isang tila hindi gaanong halaga na "bisikleta" (ang kanyang ordinaryong buhay at pang-araw-araw na gawain), ngunit ang kanyang natamo ay hindi lamang isang ligtas na pagtakas, kundi isang paggising din sa kanyang sariling bloodline na orakulo—isang paggising na nagpabago sa kanya mula sa isang "hunted ant" tungo sa isang "guardian na pinili ng isang oracleap na dimensyon," na ganap na ganap. Sa katotohanan, ang mga negosyanteng sumusuko sa matatag na trabaho at mga artisan na namumuhunan ng kanilang mga naipon sa buhay sa pagpapaunlad ng kanilang mga kasanayan ay mahalagang kinakalkula ang "asymmetric returns": kapag ang status quo na "bisikleta" ay hindi na mapanatili ang kanilang dignidad, ang presyo ng pagsusugal ay walang iba kundi ang lakas ng loob na magsimulang muli.

Ang pagbibigkis sa pag-activate ng "divine protection" na may determinasyong "lumaban": ang naghihingalong payo ng lola, "Huwag gamitin ito maliban kung ikaw ay desperado," ay nagpapahiwatig na ang kapangyarihan ng orakulo ay hindi isang walang kundisyong pagpapala, ngunit nangangailangan ng mga mortal na mag-apoy muna ng apoy ng lakas ng loob sa kanilang sarili. Ito ay umaalingawngaw sa unibersal na "kabayanihan na salaysay" ng sibilisasyon ng tao-maging si Achilles man ay naglalakas-loob sa palakpakan ng mga palaso ng Trojan o ang mga diyos ng Madilim na Kalangitan na nag-iimbak sa kanilang dugo ng banal na kapangyarihan, ang pagpapala ng mga diyos ay palaging nakasalalay sa mga taong "maglakas-loob na gawin ang unang hakbang." Ang "Pagsubok" ay, sa kaibuturan nito, ang deklarasyon ng isang mortal sa mundo, "Tumanggi akong ma-trap sa mga gear ng isang bisikleta." Ang deklarasyon na ito, tulad ng isang flint na pumuputok ng apoy, ay maaaring magpapaliwanag ng kawalan ng pag-asa at mapukaw ang natutulog na mga puwersang tagapag-alaga. Kung paanong ang banal na pattern sa likod ng leeg ni Lin Ye ay nagliliyab habang papalapit siya sa kotse, hindi ang aktibong pagkilos ng banal na orakulo, ngunit ang kanyang nag-iisang tapang ang nagbukas ng pinto sa banal na kapangyarihan.

Ang pang-akit ng "bisikleta-sa-motorsiklo" ay hindi nakasalalay sa hindi maiiwasang kahihinatnan, ngunit sa pagkilala nito sa isang malupit na katotohanan: kapag ang kaligtasan ay nabawasan sa pagkakaroon lamang ng "isang bisikleta lamang na sasakyan," ang paghihintay ay hahantong lamang sa isang mas masamang resulta. Ang mga kalye sa isang bagyo ay hindi lalawak nang mag-isa, at hindi rin magsasara ang mga humahabol na sasakyan nang mag-isa. Tanging ang lakas ng loob na paikutin ang sasakyan, ang katatagan na bumangga sa bakal, ang makakapaggising sa mahinang kislap ng banal na proteksyon sa loob ng dugo ng isang tao. Ang kislap na ito ay maaaring hindi isang supernatural na himala, ngunit ito ay ang alab ng kalikasan ng tao na tumangging lumubog—at ang lahat ng pagbabalikwas ng kapalaran ay nagsisimula sa unang pagkislap ng apoy na ito.

Sinusuri ng nasa itaas ang malalim na mga motibasyon sa likod ng "pagsusugal" mula sa mga pananaw ng lohika ng kaligtasan, batas ng kita, at espirituwal na mekanismo.

The rain in Boston was never gentle. It lashed against the cobblestones of Waverly Street, turning the historic district into a watercolor painting left out in a storm. Elias Thorne pulled his coat tighter, the wool heavy and damp against his skin. He wasn't here for the weather, though. He was here for the attic.
Number 44 Waverly Street was a townhouse that time had forgotten. It had been in the Thorne family for generations, a silent sentinel in a neighborhood of trendy cafes and renovated brownstones. Elias, the last surviving descendant, had inherited the place from his reclusive great-aunt Beatrice. The solicitor’s letter had been clear: settle the estate, sell the property.
Elias had planned to do just that. He would clear out the junk, hire an appraiser, and put the old place on the market before the winter snows hit. But as he climbed the narrow, winding stairs to the attic, a strange feeling settled over him, heavier than the damp air. It felt like he was being watched.
The attic was a cavern of shadows and dust. Sunlight, weak and gray, filtered through a single grimy dormer window, illuminating dancing motes and the shapes of shrouded furniture. The air smelled of mildew, old paper, and something else—something dry and ancient, like pressed flowers and secrets.
Elias sighed, pulling a flashlight from his pocket. "Alright, Aunt Bea," he whispered to the empty room. "Let's see what you've left me."
He spent hours cataloging the contents. There were steamer trunks filled with yellowed lace, crates of tarnished silverware, and stacks of leather-bound books with titles in languages Elias didn't recognize. It was standard heirloom fare, valuable to collectors, perhaps, but not particularly interesting to him.
Just as he was about to call it a day, his flashlight beam caught a glint of color in the far corner, behind a stack of mildewed hatboxes. He squeezed past the obstacle, coughing at the disturbed dust.
It was a small, lacquered chest. It looked Chinese, or perhaps Japanese. The red lacquer was faded, and the golden hinges were verdigris with age, but it was locked. Elias searched the floor and found a tarnished brass key nearby, as if someone had dropped it in a hurry.
Heart beating a little faster, he knelt and inserted the key. It turned with a rusty shriek. Inside, nestled on a bed of faded silk the color of dried roses, lay a single object.
It was a jade fish. Carved from a single piece of stone, it was about the size of his palm. The jade was a translucent, mossy green, and it seemed to hold the light from his flashlight, glowing with an inner luminescence. It was incredibly detailed—the scales were etched with microscopic precision, and the fish’s eye was a tiny inlay of obsidian that seemed to follow Elias’s movements.
Elias picked it up. It was cool to the touch, unnaturally so, and surprisingly heavy. As his fingers closed around it, a jolt, like a static shock but deeper, vibrated up his arm. The dusty attic seemed to fade away for a second, replaced by the scent of saltwater and the sound of distant, crashing waves.
He blinked, and the illusion vanished. He was back in the cold, damp attic, holding a piece of stone.
"What are you?" he murmured.
He spent the rest of the evening researching. He found no records of the chest, the key, or the fish in his aunt's papers. It was as if it had appeared out of thin air. The only clue was a symbol etched faintly on the bottom of the fish, a stylized wave that looked vaguely familiar.
The next morning, Elias woke with a start. He had dreamed of the ocean, of diving into deep, dark water where strange, bioluminescent fish darted past him. He rubbed his eyes and reached for the jade fish, which he had placed on his nightstand.
It was warm.
He frowned. Stone didn't retain heat, not like this. And the color seemed different, richer, greener than he remembered.

The rain in Boston was never gentle. It lashed against the cobblestones of Waverly Street, turning the historic district into a watercolor painting left out in a storm. Elias Thorne pulled his coat tighter, the wool heavy and damp against his skin. He wasn't here for the weather, though. He was here for the attic.
Number 44 Waverly Street was a townhouse that time had forgotten. It had been in the Thorne family for generations, a silent sentinel in a neighborhood of trendy cafes and renovated brownstones. Elias, the last surviving descendant, had inherited the place from his reclusive great-aunt Beatrice. The solicitor’s letter had been clear: settle the estate, sell the property.
Elias had planned to do just that. He would clear out the junk, hire an appraiser, and put the old place on the market before the winter snows hit. But as he climbed the narrow, winding stairs to the attic, a strange feeling settled over him, heavier than the damp air. It felt like he was being watched.
The attic was a cavern of shadows and dust. Sunlight, weak and gray, filtered through a single grimy dormer window, illuminating dancing motes and the shapes of shrouded furniture. The air smelled of mildew, old paper, and something else—something dry and ancient, like pressed flowers and secrets.
Elias sighed, pulling a flashlight from his pocket. "Alright, Aunt Bea," he whispered to the empty room. "Let's see what you've left me."
He spent hours cataloging the contents. There were steamer trunks filled with yellowed lace, crates of tarnished silverware, and stacks of leather-bound books with titles in languages Elias didn't recognize. It was standard heirloom fare, valuable to collectors, perhaps, but not particularly interesting to him.
Just as he was about to call it a day, his flashlight beam caught a glint of color in the far corner, behind a stack of mildewed hatboxes. He squeezed past the obstacle, coughing at the disturbed dust.
It was a small, lacquered chest. It looked Chinese, or perhaps Japanese. The red lacquer was faded, and the golden hinges were verdigris with age, but it was locked. Elias searched the floor and found a tarnished brass key nearby, as if someone had dropped it in a hurry.
Heart beating a little faster, he knelt and inserted the key. It turned with a rusty shriek. Inside, nestled on a bed of faded silk the color of dried roses, lay a single object.
It was a jade fish. Carved from a single piece of stone, it was about the size of his palm. The jade was a translucent, mossy green, and it seemed to hold the light from his flashlight, glowing with an inner luminescence. It was incredibly detailed—the scales were etched with microscopic precision, and the fish’s eye was a tiny inlay of obsidian that seemed to follow Elias’s movements.
Elias picked it up. It was cool to the touch, unnaturally so, and surprisingly heavy. As his fingers closed around it, a jolt, like a static shock but deeper, vibrated up his arm. The dusty attic seemed to fade away for a second, replaced by the scent of saltwater and the sound of distant, crashing waves.
He blinked, and the illusion vanished. He was back in the cold, damp attic, holding a piece of stone.
"What are you?" he murmured.
He spent the rest of the evening researching. He found no records of the chest, the key, or the fish in his aunt's papers. It was as if it had appeared out of thin air. The only clue was a symbol etched faintly on the bottom of the fish, a stylized wave that looked vaguely familiar.
The next morning, Elias woke with a start. He had dreamed of the ocean, of diving into deep, dark water where strange, bioluminescent fish darted past him. He rubbed his eyes and reached for the jade fish, which he had placed on his nightstand.
It was warm.
He frowned. Stone didn't retain heat, not like this. And the color seemed different, richer, greener than he remembered.

Summer in London had settled into a warm, golden rhythm. Streets hummed with laughter and twinkling café evenings. For Amelia, every day felt like another page turned — and every choice she made was hers alone.

Her days had taken on a satisfying cadence: teaching, researching, walking through the city, sometimes stopping to sit on a bench near the Thames just to watch the sunlight dance on the water.

She was happy — not because life was perfect — but because she chose what her life meant.

Julian and Amelia’s connection deepened in that gentle way true partnerships often do — not rushed, not intense, but noticeable in small gestures:

✨ Shared notebooks with scribbled poem lines,
✨ Coffee cups left on tables long after conversations had faded,
✨ Comfortable silences that felt like warmth rather than voids.

Their chemistry wasn’t brazen fireworks…
but steady, affectionate embers.

One afternoon, as they walked through a farmers’ market near Portobello Road, Julian paused beside a stand of sunflowers — tall, vibrant, reaching toward the sky.

“Reminds me of you,” he said gently, brushing a petal with his finger.

Amelia felt her heart lighten. It wasn’t a grand moment — just sincere, grounded, real.

And that mattered.

Meanwhile, miles away, Miles Turner was navigating growth of his own — not by chasing what he lost, but by building something meaningful.

He had officially launched the Turner Scholarship for Personal Growth and Leadership — a fund dedicated to giving emerging leaders not just financial support, but access to mentorship, community, and emotional wellness programs. His proposal wasn’t about legacy anymore; it was about impact.

At the launch event, he spoke not as an heir with a status to defend — but as a person who had struggled, learned, and grown.

“…We all carry the potential to change — not when someone else loves us, but when we love ourselves enough to become better,” he said, steady and heartfelt.

As applause filled the room, he felt something settle inside him — a peace that wasn’t hollow, but fundamental.

Across the sea, Amelia sat at a small café with Julian, watching the sun dip behind rooftops.

“You feel different,” Julian said thoughtfully, “like you’re not chasing anyone — you’re choosing what matters.”

Amelia smiled. “I am,” she said — because she had learned to trust her voice, her pace, and her heart.

Not rushing love.
Not clinging to the past.
Just living it.

And as London’s twilight wrapped around them like a promise, she realized:

Sometimes the best parts of love aren’t the grand gestures —
They’re the quiet bridges between two people who see each other for who they truly are.

It was the exact style I loved most.
I had been waiting for this wedding for seven years. I never expected my husband to be preparing a surprise for me—but why wasn’t the size mine?
I pretended I’d seen nothing, folded the order slip neatly, and put it back in his pocket.

“Is this Ms. Clara Bennett? Your mother, Sophia, was pushed down the stairs. She has intracranial bleeding and needs emergency surgery. We’re still short fifty thousand for the deposit. Please bring it over immediately, or we won’t be able to start the operation!”
The doctor’s voice was rushed and cold, like a bucket of ice water poured straight over my head.
My mind went blank with a loud buzz. I grabbed my wallet, snatched my keys, and rushed downstairs.
Wasn’t my mom supposed to be picking Noah up from kindergarten?
How could she have been pushed down the stairs?

Insufficient balance.
I clenched the cards in my fingers, the cold plastic edges digging painfully into my skin.
All these cards had been set up for me by Liam. He’d always said the household money was mine to manage—he earned it, I just needed to stay home and live peacefully.
And now, every cent was gone.
There was no time to argue. I turned and ran home.

It was my husband.

And the words he spoke were knives dipped in poison.
“My Vanessa really is the sweetest. That necklace looks perfect on you.”
His fingers brushed over the dazzling sparkle at her throat.
My pupils shrank violently.
That was the diamond necklace I’d admired in magazines for ages. On my last birthday, I’d asked Liam for it. He’d wrapped an arm around me and said, “Too flashy. It doesn’t suit you. Simple things look better on you.”
Then he took me to a street stall and bought me a plastic one.
So it wasn’t that it didn’t suit me.
He just never intended to give it to me.
Vanessa giggled and snuggled closer, her fingers tracing his chest flirtatiously.
“Liam, you’re so good to me. You even bought this because you knew I’d like it. But… you used my sister’s card to buy me a gift. Won’t she get angry if she finds out?”
“Her?” Liam snorted, his tone both indulgent and cruel.
“That blockhead probably won’t even notice the money’s gone. Besides, what’s hers isn’t mine? Even her little stash of private savings—didn’t I use that to buy you jewelry too?”
My nails dug deep into my palms.
That money… I’d saved it desperately before marriage by working part-time jobs. It was meant to be my last line of defense.
He’d been eyeing it all along.
“You really are the good one,” Liam murmured as he lowered his head to kiss Vanessa’s collarbone.
“Not like that useless Clara. Can’t even keep a child. Three of them. Three. Pregnant, lost it. Pregnant again, lost it again. Such a waste of my time.”
Vanessa laughed sweetly, her voice dripping with sugar.

My breathing stopped.
Wasn’t Noah adopted because Liam couldn’t bear to see me lose another child?

Every word was a red-hot iron rod, stabbing straight into my ears and branding my soul.

All of it was a carefully woven lie.
A long, brutal sacrifice—paved with the flesh and blood of my own children—to build their love.
“That’s only because I didn’t want to get married yet, so I let her raise Noah,” Vanessa sneered.
“She treats him like her heart and soul. Feeding him, telling him stories, picking him up from school—she has no idea she’s raising a child who survived by drinking her own baby’s blood. Pathetic and stupid.”
“Noah is our son,” Liam said with a smile.
“She’s happy to be a free nanny. Saves trouble. You can focus on your dance career and secure Mr. G’s investment. Isn’t your father pushing you to marry that fool from the Nicholson family—Gregory? The Nicholson family…
That heir rumored to be disabled from an accident, with a gloomy, twisted personality—Gregory Nicholson?
A substitute bride.
My blood froze completely.
They wanted my children’s lives.

And now they wanted to squeeze out my last bit of value and throw me to another man like trash.

“Would she dare?” Liam’s tone turned cold.
“Her mother Sophia’s medical bills—every bit of her follow-up treatment—is in my hands. Clara’s the submissive type. For her mom, she’ll swallow any humiliation. And besides—”
He paused, his contempt naked.
“A housewife I’ve supported for years. Her bank cards are with me, her documents are with me, and she’s long lost contact with her friends. Without me, she wouldn’t last three days. Once she’s sent into the Nicholson family, she can scream all she wants—no one will hear her.”

Not yet.

Mr. G.

I gave it all up for my marriage with Liam.
That year, he handed me a pure black business card—only a name and a handwritten number.
